heading: Bachelor of Pharmacy (B.Pharma)
description: B.Pharm is a 4-year undergraduate degree that focuses on drug science, development, & manufacturing, and patient care. The core subjects in the course include Pharmacology, Pharmaceutics, Pharmaceutical Chemistry, Pharmacognosy, Biochemistry, and Anatomy. Shivalik College of Pharmacy is the Best College for B.Pharma in Dehradun, offering quality pharmaceutical education with a focus on research and industry readiness.

eligibility.heading: Eligibility Criteria
eligibility.general: Candidates shall have passed 10+2 examination conducted by the respective state/central government authorities recognized as equivalent to 10+2 examination with English as one of the subjects and Physics, Chemistry, Mathematics (P.C.M) and or Biology (PCB / PCMB) as optional subjects individually. Any other qualification approved by the Pharmacy Council of India as equivalent to any of the above examinations.
lateralEntry: A pass in D. Pharm. course from an institution approved by the Pharmacy Council of India under section 12 of the Pharmacy Act

faqs.question: Is B.Pharm better than MBBS?
faqs.answer: B.Pharm and MBBS serve different career goals. While MBBS focuses on clinical practice, B.Pharm offers wider career options in the pharmaceutical industry, research, and healthcare sectors, making it a flexible and practical choice for many students.

faqs.question: What are some careers in Biology?
faqs.answer: Top biology careers include Pharmacy, Biotechnology, Microbiology, Clinical Research, and Biomedical Sciences. Pharmacy leads with strong job demand, industry exposure, and diverse career paths.

faqs.question: Which job is best without NEET?
faqs.answer: Careers without NEET include Pharmacy, Biotechnology, Microbiology, and Clinical Research. Pharmacy is preferred for its stability, growth, and healthcare relevance.

faqs.question: What are some best courses after 12th with PCB?
faqs.answer: Popular courses include B.Pharm, Biotechnology, Microbiology, and Life Sciences. B.Pharm stands out for its career scope and industry-focused learning.
